DedooseR 0.0.2

Clean and harmonize coded excerpts, keep preferred coder, and attach a codebook

Source: R/clean_data.R
clean_data.Rd

Reads (optionally) an Excel file of excerpts, normalizes column names, converts Dedoose-style code columns (names starting with code and ending with applied) to binary c_* variables, and keeps only the most-preferred coder's excerpts per transcript. Also applies human-readable variable labels and attaches a simple codebook as an attribute.

Usage

clean_data(excerpts, preferred_coders)

Arguments

excerpts

A data frame of excerpts or a single-length character file path to an .xlsx file. If a path is provided, it is read via readxl::read_xlsx(col_types = "text") and then processed.

preferred_coders

Character vector of coder names ordered from most- to least-preferred. Used to select the coder to retain within each transcript (media_title).

Value

A base data.frame with:

  • normalized column names,

  • binary c_* columns (0/1; may contain NA),

  • only the preferred coder's excerpts per media_title,

  • attached variable labels (via labelled).

Additionally, a data.frame codebook is attached as attr(result, "codebook") with columns variable, label, and type.

Details

Name normalization

  • All column names are converted to lowercase and spaces are replaced with underscores.

  • If present, excerpt_copy is renamed to excerpt.

  • Columns with names ending in "range" or "weight" are dropped.

Code columns -> binary c_*

  • Columns whose names match ^code.*applied$ are interpreted as Dedoose code flags. Their contents are coerced using tolower(trimws(x)) == "true" and then cast to numeric (TRUE -> 1, FALSE -> 0; NA remains NA).

  • Those columns are then renamed: remove the leading code token and the trailing applied, sanitize punctuation/spaces to underscores, and prefix with "c_" (e.g., code "Help" applied -> c_help).

  • As a safeguard, all columns starting with c_ are coerced to numeric 0/1 via as.numeric(as.logical(x)).

Preferred coder filtering

  • Within each media_title, the function computes the coder's rank via match(excerpt_creator, preferred_coders) and retains all rows from the single most-preferred coder present (ties are broken by first match in preferred_coders; other coders' rows are removed).

Labels and codebook

  • Applies descriptive labels to common columns (e.g., media_title, excerpt_creator, excerpt_date, excerpt, etc.) using labelled::var_label().

  • Auto-labels every c_* variable with its own name.

  • Builds a simple codebook with variables, labels, and types and attaches it as attr(x, "codebook").

Requirements

The input must contain at least media_title and excerpt_creator. If you want automatic code detection, code variables should follow the pattern ^code.*applied$ prior to renaming.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# From a data frame
df <- data.frame(
  media_title = c("T1","T1","T2"),
  excerpt_creator = c("Ann","Bob","Ann"),
  `code "Help" applied` = c("TRUE","false", NA),
  code_harm_applied = c("true","true","false"),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)
clean <- clean_data(df, preferred_coders = c("Ann","Bob"))
attr(clean, "codebook")  # access the attached codebook

# From a file path (all columns initially read as text)
# clean <- clean_data("path/to/excerpts.xlsx", preferred_coders = c("Ann","Bob","Cara"))
} # }
